div.head: The Plague.
div.p: Today's bulletin records a recovery at Suez, but no fresh cases.

div.head: Cable-Ship.
div.p: The Eastern Telegraph Company's cable- ship Duplex arrived at Alexandria this morning from Malta.

div.head: Benha Provincial Councill-
div.p: Wednesday's sitting of the provincial council at Benha was occupied with irrigation questions.

div.head: Savoy Hotel.
div.p: We are informed that the Savoy Hotel, Cairo, will open its doors for the season on the 1st December.

div.head: Egypt's Wealth
div.p: The actual amount of bullion from England imported into Egypt this autumn has been seven millions sterling.

div.head: M. Suares' Bequest
div.p: The late M. Felix Suarez bequeathed the sum of 10,000 francs to the Mussulman Benevolent Society. This sum was lately made over to it.

div.head: Sudan Irrigation.
div.p: The Public Works Department has appointed thirteen new irrigation engineers for the Sudan. They have already left for their posts.

div.head: A Brute In Human Form.
div.p: A Cairo youth has been arrested on the charge of committing a criminal offence on a little girl of 18 near a cafe at Rod-el-Farag, where he outraged the child after administering opium.

div.head: Hamburg-America Line.
div.p: The magnificent S.Y. Oceana arrived this morning from Genoa and Naples with a large number of distinguished passengers on board. The yacht was dressed rainbow fashion in honor of the Khedive's departure for Cairo.

div.head: Italian Colony.
div.p: The new Italian Government School at Boulao is to be opened shortly, and the classes started immediately. The proposed consular buildings are to be erected on a plot of land owned by the Italian Government close to the school.

div.head: corporation of Western- Egypt, limited.
div.p: Major General Sir John Ardagh, K.C.M.G., K.C.I.E., C.B., R.E., British Government director of the Suez Canal Company, has joined the board of the Corporation of Western Egypt, Ltd., and has accepted the chairmanship of the board.

div.head: St Andrew's Dinner.
div.p: A correspondent writes:—The intention of celebrating the 30th November by a dinner in Cairo has appeared in more than one newspaper. The promoters will do well if they would state publicly to whom persons wishing to be present should apply.

div.head: The Cairo Press.
div.p: The printers' strike at the "Pyramides" and "Bourse Egyptienne" at Cairo still countinue. The men on strike have decided to found a new daily newspaper entitled "L'Echo Egyptienne." The new Cairo daily newspaper "L'Orient". will appear in a day or two.

div.head: Alhambra Theatre.
div.p: The Silvestre French comedy company will give a performance this evening of Rostand's well-known comedy "Cyrano de Bergerac" in which M. Silvestre will assume the title role. To-morrow, ' Champignol malgré lui!" will be given in the afternoon and "Le Juif Errant" in the evening.

div.head: Coal Imports.
div.p: Our imports of coal at Alexandria between January 1 and November 22. of this year, total 1,181 047 tons, composed as follows: Welsh, 645.947 tons; Newcastle, 201,088 tons; Scotch, 108,223 tons; Yorkshire 169,670 tons ; other qualities, 50,119 tons. The total for the same period last year was 974,918 tons.

div.head: Gruesome Find,
div.p: Gruesome was the discovery made by fields labourers of a village near Tantah, the other day, when they found the body of a man, who had been stabbed to death. The police investigation has established that the murderer had evidently attempted to throw the body of his victim into the Nile.

div.head: Academy for Egypt
div.p: A scheme is said to be on toot for converting the Khedivial Medical Society into an Academy, whose membership is to be limited. Thus converted, the Academy will have a complete laboratory for chemical and microscopic research, to be divided into several sections. There is evidence to show that the Academy would enjoy the moral and material support of the Egyptian Government and the Diplomatic Body.

TRIAL LESSONS FREE
Situation in Egypt
Foreign Secretary's Statement
(Gazette's Speical Service.)
London, Friday, Nov. 23.

An important statement was made in the House of Commons last night, which will, it is considered, have an excellent effect in England and on the Continent in removing the misapprehensions as to the state of public security in that country, which have been encouraged by the tactics of a section of extreme Radical Little Englander members of the House of Commons in lending their support to Egyptian Nationalist agitators and Mr. Wilfrid Blunt.

The Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs, in reply to some questions put by members of Parliament as to the present situation in Egypt, declared that the actual condition of affairs throughout that country was not now giving any grounds for special anxiety, and there was not the slightest reason for those wishing to visit that country in the course of the winter season being discouraged from putting their intentions into execution. This reply of Sir Edward Grey will have a very satisfactory result, for some timid and ill-informed people have been quite alarmed by the rumors as to the disaffection prevailing in Egypt, which have been fanned by a small group of the Liberal party.
Artin Pasha's Resignation
(Gazette's Special Service.)
London, Friday, Nov. 23.

The Foreign Secretary declared, in reply to another question on the recent appointment of a Minister of Public Instruction, that the selection of Saad Bey Zighloul had been received with general and great approval by all classes of the inhabitants of Egypt. Sir Eiward Grey added that he was quite unable to admit, that, the late Under Secretary of State for the Ministry of Public Instruction, Yacoub Pasha Artin, had any grievance against the Egyptian Government in regard to the appointment in question, but that he regretted the resignation of that distinguished scholar and official.

div.head: Mr. Robertson and Egypt
div.p: To the Editor of the "Egyptian Gazette."

Dear Mr. Editor,—With reference to the paragraph in your issue of the 20th instant on Mr. Robertson's visit to Egypt, I am sure it will come as a great blow to the majority of your readers to learn that this estimable gentleman is not coming to Egypt after all. His recent interesting question in Parliament anent our culpable waste of Nile and shows the profound and intimate knowledge he possesses of Egyptian irrigation, and, one may say, of Egypt generally, and doubtless the Advisers to the Egyptian Government would have eagerly embraced the opportunity of conferring with an Irrigation expert of Mr. Robertson's standing.—I am, etc.,
Ignoramus Stupendissimus.
Cairo, November 21st.

div.head: New National Policy
div.p: There is a widespread belief in native circles in Cairo that the tour of inspection which Mustapha Pasha Fehmy, the Prime Minister, has just undertaken in the Dakahlieh Moudirieh. is the first step in the direction of a new national policy, the object of which is to teach the country to accord to the Ministers of the Government the honor and distinction which are due to them.

div.head: Minieh Agricultural Show
div.p: The Minieh Agricultural Show, which is to be held on the 29th inst., is expected to be a most successful function, and notwithstanding rumors to the contrary, it is thought that the Khedive will honor the Show with his presence. A luncheon for one hundred persons will be provided and the catering has been placed in the hands of the Grand Continental Hotel.
Omar Bey Sultan will give two banquets at his palace at Minieh on the 29th and 30th inst.

div.head: Army Of Occupation.
div.p: A Staff ride will be carried out in Cairo on December 3 by officers of the Army of Occupation. Major General Bollock, C.B., acting as director in chief.

In previous years it has been found that musketry has suffered by the scarcity of range equipment. In view of the increased garrison, commandants have been requested to see that they have sufficient targets and range equipment generally in reserve to stand the strain of the coming musketry season.

The third military lecture of the winter season will he delivered by Capt. and Adjt. SE McI. Lomer, 1st Lancashire Fusiliers, on. "Surprise in War," at. 6 p m. on Tuesday, the 27th inst, in the Model Room at Headquarters, Cairo

div.head: THE KHEDIVE.
div.p: Departure for Cairo.
H.H. the Khedive officially left Alexandria for Cairo for the winter season this morning.

Cherif Pasha street was be flagged for the occasion, and the entry to the Moharrem Bey station was decorated with shrubs. In the station yard a battalion of the Egyptian Army, with band and colour, and the Alexandria Fire Brigade were stationed.

His Highness arrived at the station from Ras el Tin about 7.20 o'clock and walked down the platform followed by Prince Aziz Pasha Hassan, Mustapba Pasha Fehmy, President of the Council of Ministers, the Ministers, Sir Vincent Corbett, the Financial Adviser, and the chief members of the Khedivial Household. A large gathering of European and native officials, officers of the Army of Occupation, and representatives of European Society, were present to salute the Khedive on his departure. After shaking hands with those present, his Highness proceeded to inspect the guard of honour of the Army of Occupation, which was drawn up on the platform.

The railway arrangements were most efficiently carried out under the personal supervision of Captain Hall, R.E, Traffic Manager, who accompanied the train to Cairo, as also did the General-Manager of the Egyptian State Railways, Miralai Macaulay Bey, Mr. Trevithick, chief mechanical engineer, and Mr. Versohoyle, chief engineer of the Permanent Way.
His Highness stepped into the train at 7:30 o'clock, and it steamed out of the station amidst a salute of twenty-one guns from Fort Kom el Dumas.

At all the stations en route the Khedivial train arrived to the minute and all the chief stations were lavishly decorated, while enthusiastic crowds greeted the passage of his Highness with loyal salutations.

div.head: Arrival in Cairo
div.p: (By Telephone)

In anticipation of the Khedive's arrival at Cairo, at half past eleven this morning, the principal buildings on the route from the station to Abdeen Palace had been amply decorated with banting and flags representing every nationality. More than an hour before the train was due, small crowds of natives began to collect in the streets, and by 11.15 the balconies of Shepheard's and the Grand Continental Hotels were crowded with a fashionable assemblege of sightseers. Excellent order was kept by the police, who regulated the traffic well until the Khedivial carriage had passed.

As the Khedivial train drew up at the North arrival platform punctual to the minute the bands of the Lancashire Fusiliers, and Egyptian Cavalry and Infantry played the Khedivial Hymn, at the conclusion of which his Highness made his exit, shaking hands with the distinguished personages who had come to greet him.
The Khedive proceeded straight to Abdeen Palace, where he will remain till this evening, when he goes to Koubbeh.
The streets were open to traffic too soon after the Khedivial cortège had passed and- much confusion ensued.
The Inniskillings will give a military concert this evening at the Continental Hotel in honoor of the arrival of the Khedive, and many buildings in Cairo will be illuminated.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS
div.p: The Messageries Maritimes S.S. Niger, which left Alexandria on Sunday morning, arrived at Marseilles yesterday morning.
The Norddentscher Lloyd S.S. Schleswig left Naples yesterday and is due at Alexandria at 3 p.m. on Monday.

div.head: France and Egypt
div.p: Commerical Convention Promulgated
A Havas telegram from Paris states that the French "Journal Officiel" has promulgated the commercial convention between France and Egypt.

div.head:
KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
ADDITION TO RED SEA FLEET.
div.p: (From our Correspondent.)
Suez, Friday.
The Khedivial Mail S.S. Co. have just made an important addition to their Red Sea fleet, by the purchase of the S.S. Safari from Messrs. Cowasjee Dinshaw & Bros., Aden.

This steamer originally belonged to the Deutsch Oat Afrika Linie, and has excellent saloon accommodation. Her registered tonnage is 1,432 tons, and she promises to be one of the company's most comfortable ships for the Red Sea trade, as she was specially built in 1892 for tropical climates. The Safari was transferred to the Kbedivial Company a few days ago and was re-named the Mansourah.
We understand that the Company are also acquiring another similar vessel for the Red Sea service.

div.head: RAMLEH RAILWAY.
div.p: The question of prolonging the Ramleh railway line from the present oity terminus to point in Mi hamed Aly-square has now been under the consideration of the Alexandria Municipality for two years past, and there is every likelihood of the project still remaining under the municipal consideration. The difficulty is that nothing has been decided definitely as to the great boulevard that is to extend along the quay. When this question is settled the Railway Company will be allowed to lay its lines along this thoroughfare and to remove the terminus from its present position to the square. This will be a great convenience to all the inhabitants of Ramleh.
The present line of tramway along the Ramleh Boulevard will continue as at present. The goods services will have its headquarters at the existing terminus, as is now the case.

div.head: ALEXANDRIA TRAMWAY CO.
div.p: The Alexandria Tramway Company intend to considerably increase their electric power station in the Karmous quarter of Alexandria. The extension will consist of a completely new installation of a steam turbine engine of about 2,000 H. P. A continuous current dynamo of corresponding size, and four new tubular boilers, which have already arrived, will be erected there shortly.

The company intend to extend their service along the new quay from the Rue Champollion. near the General Post Office, to Fort Kaid Bey as soon as the necessary authorisation has been obtained from the Alexandria Municipality.
The Municipality, judging from the time it takes to consider new schemas, is very much slower in arriving at a decision than the Public Works Ministry.

div.head: "LA CHATELAINE."
div.p: 'La Chaelaine" is hardly an easy play to judge at first sight, or in a theatre where the acoustics are bad. I had never seen or read it, and being in the eighth row of the stalls, I could not hear half that was said. It is certainly a complete change from Dumas; it is natural, witty, worldly, turning on the question of a divorce, and an intrigue, or rather sustained effort, to marry Lucienne, the "jeune fille" in the piece, to Neray instead of Jossan. There is no very startling passion, crime, sentiment at its greater depths; it is just the story for the chateau where it takes place. The people, wellborn, interesting, and amusing, have in their lives just what supplies a special emotion now and again, and always an interest separate from more common place existences. Mme Hading, of course, has the exact note, as the perfect comedienne moundaine et aristocrate ; and though, as I have said, the play is too natural to move an audience profoundly, too well written and interesting, too near the lives of many of us perhaps, to rouse greater emotions, yet her presence on the stage was, so to express it, the play and the whole play, a keen pleasure to watch; and the moment she was off the stage the life seemed to leave it.

This sounds hard on the other actors; and I do not mean that the play lost interest, but the vitality that held as ebbed and flowed with her absence or presence. Mme. Florian and M. Garat as the de Morenes were certainly excellent, characteristic, amusing, if a trifle forced at moments. Lucienne (Mile. Mac-Leane) was very charming. M. Arnaud again was the thorough homme da monde" as we have already seen him. I except from the ' rived this morning by the Hamburg-American "loss of vitality" charge his talk with Gaston liner Oceans, de River on dueling. He had some delightful things to say, and he said them admirably, giving the exact value to every point: "Je n'ai, poar ainsi dire, jamais ete tnd !"— most clever of many clever sayings ! He marked them all without over emphasizing any. It is certainly a play to see and to read more than once for its quiet wit and truth, and (can one use the phrase ?) perfect breeding I apologize for the word, but English is not the best of tongues for criticism of drama. One has to take what one can get.

div.head: La Chaelaine
div.p: Sapho

'Sapho" is surely the greatest impersonation Jane Hading has given so far. Such a change is it, such a totally different side of life! We all know the tale, the attraction at first sight of the young man and the girl "qui se cram- ponne." She has lived with a poet, a sculptor, a forger, the father of her child, and now she finds the real love with her student. Jane Hading is Sapho alive and actual, no longer repentant or injured, and provincial aristocrat, but simply the daughter of her disreputable coachman father, rising from that level by contact with so many celebrities, but returning to it in the moments of greater emotion. And what moments those were! The burning of the letters, that farewell in the third act— ah one more minute of that voice, and how much self-control would we have kept? And the last of all farewells, when she never spoke, but every look was a word, an appeal, an expectation! And the other side, as loving menagere, debraillee, in her attitude at the piano. We know "Voi che sapete." Cherubin comes forward after due preparation, sings the exquisite song, his one chance in an exquisite opera. But how often do we see and hear her version, her voice asking ourselves what we know of our own hearts, so direct, sweet, poignant? So might someone ask to whom love is all life and not a mere incident for applause from a cultivated musical audience. Again, her "engeulade" was a miracle, indescribable; but then the whole performance was that. What was she going to say next, to look next and why could not each instant live for hours?

The other artistes were far better than usual. All seemed to have woken up. Mr. Arnaud, we must say, was in a sense eclipsed for once he was(the part is hard and lends itself to this) over emphasized. Perhaps Dechelette was the best, though the crucial moment, the death of his Alice Dore, brought out a certain theatricalism. It may be right and intentional, but it might have been more reserved, and so, far more striking. Caondal (Mr. Grammont) was excellent: the Hetle- mas, lren6, Sanchez, Papa Legrand, were all that one wished and expected. In fact, it was a triumph with scarcely a wrong note anywhere—a great fantasia de braille—again the word; I find no translation for it—and with that deep note of love passing, weaving its way throughout. Incidentally we are the richer tor the word "quitterie"—better than separation, or divorce, or forgetting, a greater impersonation that has made it a living experience and perhaps a lasting memory for those who heard it.

We must add one word; certain details, slight but annoying. Why do the management sell seats, and especially the Press seat, twice over! 1 Et a la premiere vetrue pardossus le marche !" And why is it that in every Egyptian theatre the performance must be a descent to ground-bars of gusts of coughing, and trampling of innumerable—recruits—in corridors! Oh for immoveable seats, even chairs, to prevent listeners (sic!) from moving and shuffling; and even chloroform would be welcome if the constant misplaced throat noises strange and obscene, could thereby he quelled, enabling a luckless but fascinated listener in a back row to hear what the actors say.
Lord Cromer has made a Beyram contribution to the funds of the Orwael Woska Benevolent Society.

Ghazi Mukhtar Pasha, Imperial Ottoman High Commissioner, accompanied by his civil and military households, will leave Alexandria (Hadra Station) on Monday next by special train at 7.20 a.m. for Cairo, where he will arrive at 12.35 p.m.
Saad Pasha Zaghloul, Minister of Public Instruction, has requested the Government to provide him with a private secretary, as in the case of the other Ministers.
M. de la Bouliniere, the retiring French Diplomatic Agent, will present his letters of recall in the course of an audience of the Khedive at Abdeen Palace on Monday.
Mr. A Smyrnoff, Russian Consul General in Egypt, arrived at Alexandria yesterday by the Russian steamer Tohihatchoff.
Boghos Pasha Nubar and his family are expected to arrive in Egypt at the end of this month. They are staying at their Parisian residence in the Avenue do Trocadero.
Lady Rogers was among the passengers by the Hamburg-American liner S.S Oceana which arrived at Alexandria this from Genoa and Naples.
Mrs. George Nungovich Bey and her charming daughter, Miss Marietta Nungovich, arrived this morning by the Hamburg American liner Oceane.
Mr. Randolph Berens and suite, of London alto arrived this morning by the S.Y. Oceane.

Mr. Bernhard Kant, one of the managers of the Hambarg America Line, arrived this morning by the company's S.S. Oceana and proceeded by the evening train to Cairo accompanied by Mr. D. E. Munari, the company's local manager in Cairo.
The passengers who left for Marseilles by the Congo yesterday were Mme Caudau, Mr. Meldon, Mr. Goerin, Rev. Dariaa, Mr. Talon, Mme Durand, and Mr. Meanier.

A very pretty wedding was celebrated at All Saints' Church, Cairo, on Thursday last, when Miss Florence Curtis, daughter of Mr. H. Curtis, of the Government Arsenal, Boulac, was married to Mr. Percy Glyn Hopson, of the Bank of Egypt, Cairo. The ceremony was performed by the Very Rev. Dean Butcher, D.D., assisted by the Rev. Burns. Mr. W.H. Hill acted as "best man," and the bridesmaids were Miss Edith Hayes and Miss Florence Lloyd. After the religious ceremony a reception was held at the Arsenal, Boulac, and subsequently the newly wedded pair left, amid a shower of rose leaves and confetti, en route for Ramleh, where the first portion of the honeymoon will be spent at the New Victoria Hotel:
(Amended Notice)

An examination will be held at Cairo Post Office at 9 a m. on the 29th instant and at Alexandria Post Office, at 9 a m. on the 4th December next for the purpose of examining candidates for position of clerks and apprentices in those towns.
Candidates for clerkships must have the Secondary Certificate of Education and, if successful, will be employed at L.E. 7 per i mouth.
Candidates for apprenticeships must hold the Primary Certificates of Education and, if successful, will be employed at L.E. 3 per month, rising to L. E. 5 on conclusion of apprenticeship.

Intending applicants must obtain a Ministerial Form No. 167 C. G. from the Government and forward it made out in their own handwriting in Arabic and English or French to the Postmaster General, General Post Office, Alexandria, not later than the 25th inst. for Cairo and the 1st December for Alexandria.
The following documents must accompany the applications :
1—Birth Certificate.

—Certificate made on stamped paper, value 30 Milliemes, to the effect that the candidate is of Egyptian Nationality, and signed by two cadre employes of the Government in receipt of L.E. 10 per mensem or upwards and counter-signed by their Chiefs.
— Certificate of good conduct on stamped paper, value 30 Milliemes, signed by two cadre employes as stated above.

4.Secondary or Primary Education certificate delivered by the Ministry of Public Instruction within the last three years, or discharge certificate given by any Government Administration in which the candidate was employed in the cadre. 28877-1

div.head:
American Commerical Development
A Policy of Steamships

div.p: Speaking at Kansas City, the Secretary of State, Mr. Shaw, said that the first half of this century would witness the greatest commercial conflicts in history. He urged the necessity for Americans developing the new markets South America, South Africa, and the Orient with the use of American ships.
At St. Louis, Mr. Root stated that a congressional bill had been drafted establishing six subsidized steamship lines for foreign porta
(Reuter)
The Turkish commissioners hiving rejected the limitation of the frontier proposed by the Persian delegates, the latter have referred to Teheran for fresh instructions. ( Reuter)

div.head:
King George In Rome
GRECO-ITALIAN FRIENDSHIP.

div.p: The King of Greece has arrived. King Emmanuel met him at the station. (Reuter)
King George of Grrece was greatly cheered In the toasts which they exchanged the two Sovereigns drank to the good relations and progress of the two countries. (Havas)
Signor Caruso was fined 10 dollars. The police did not produce the woman whom he was (alleged) to have annoyed. She declared she could not face the crowd of moral perverts frequenting police courts.
It is alleged that Signor Caruso annoyed other women.
The defensecontended that the woman was an employee of the police and that the story was a wicked lie. An appeal against the decision has been lodged. (Reuter)
At the Conference of Naval Architects it was announced that the Government intended to introduce turbines into the navy. The Emperor was present. (Reuter)
House of Commons.—The Merchant Shipping Acts Bill was read for the third time.
(Reuter)
House of Commons. — The Land Tenure Bill was read for the third time. {Renter)
Colonel Colin Mackenzie succeeds Colonel Gerald Kitson as commandant of the Royal Military College, Sandhurst. (Reuter)
Viscount Hampden, G.C.M.G., is dead. {R.)

Henry Robert Brand, Viscount Hampden, G.C.M.G., D.L., J.P., came of a historic family, dating from 1307, the first Baron having been a distinguished officer in the reigns of Edward II. and III. The Barony was raised to the Peerage in 1884, the first Viscount being Speaker of the Honse of Commons 1872-84. Viscount Robert, who was the 24th Baron Dacre, was born on May 2, 1841 ; he married twice: in 1864, Victoria, daughter of Jean Sylvain van de Weyer; in 1868, Susan Henrietta, daughter of Lord George Cavendish. Educated at Rugby, be entered the Guards, from which he retired with the rank of captain to enter Parliament, and sat for Herefordshire, 1865 73, and Strond. 1874. 1880-85, and 1886.

He left Parliament to become Surveyor General Of Ordnance, 1883 85; and subsequently was Governor and Commander in Chief of New South Wales 1895 93. The Ho ». T. W. Brand, who is also an army man, succeeds his lather in the title.
Manchester November Handicap. Betting : 9 to 1 against Speculator; 10 to 1 Goring Heath, Cherryripe, and Magic Balm; 11 to l Great Soot and Golden Measure. (Reuter)

div.head:
French Naval Policy
VALUE OF HIGH SEA SQUADRON8.

div.p: The Chamber of Deputies, by 393 votes to 119, approved the Government's naval construction policy and confirmed the vote of the last Parliament authorizing the laying down of six new battleships this year. M. Thomson defended the building of high sea squadrons, declaring-that the Japanese would have been helpless with only a defensive navy. He did not deny the utility of submarines, but the experimental stage was still unconcluded. (R.)
Marines are mobilizing at Cadiz, Ferrol, and Cartagena to be in readiness to embark for Morocco. {Reuter)

The Church inventories continue to be the cause of marked disorder. Repeated charges of infantry and cavalry have failed to dislodge the defenders at Plouguernean (Finisterre). Reinforcements have been summoned. {Reuter)

div.head: Fearfully Bloodless
div.p: Thousands of Miserable Girls
Suffer from this Serious Evil.
Anaemic, Hysterical, Weak.
When Almost Lifeless this Victim
Found Now Blood, New Strength In
Dr. Williams' Pink. Pills.
In business, earning her own living away from home, and having to continue duties in spite of keen suffering, the case of Miss Harriett Cracknell will appeal to thousands of her sex.

Miss Cracknell is employed at a great fermions hotel in London, hot her home is at Keeper's Cottage, Faygate, Sussex. To a newspaper representative she explained how she found a complete cure for anemia in Dr. Williams' Pink Pills for Pale People.

"I had never been blessed with robust health, owing to my blood being very poor, she said, "and two years ago my health began to fail and I lost strength rapidly. At last I was incapable of fulfilling my duties, and in consequence was obliged to leave my situation. I seemed to make no progress under a doctor's care, so I went to St. George's Hospital for treatment where I was told that I was very anemic. My system was so reduced that I felt 1 could not keep any situation long. All my colour had fled. I could not eat. Sometimes I fancied a meal, but when food was placed before me I could not touch it. I passed sleepless nights, and each morning I was so tired. My eyes grew dull and ached incessantly, and dark rings formed beneath them. My lips were pale, and the lobes of my ears were transparent. The least exertion exhausted me. If I went upstairs I had to cling to the banisters for support. After a short walk I would be overcome with breathlessness and violent palpitation. Everything would grow dim before my eyes, and throbbing pains attacked my head; I would have to rest for an hour before I was fit to move again. I was also troubled with buzzing noises in my ears, and was a martyr to splitting headaches. All the day I hung about languid and weary, with no life in me. I grew dreadfully thin. All the blood seemed to have left my body. Always low-spirited and depressed, I grew highly I hysterical. If anyone spoke to me I would cry, for no reason whatever. At times I could have fainted away from sheer weakness. When night came on I could hardly crawl into bed. I still attended the Hospital regularly, but I knew I could not go on much longer, and I grew exceedingly low and despondent.

"Just at this time Dr. Williams' Pink Pills come to my mind, and I determined to try them. It was remarkable How great an improvement gradually followed their use. First, I regained an appetite. Gradually my colour came back, my eyes cleared, and the dark circles disappeared from under them. I began look forward to my meals. With every dose of Dr. Williams' Pink Pills I gained fresh strength, my friends noticed how well I was looking and that I was not so thin. Before very long 1 was absolutely well and strong; yet I had taken only a few boxes of Dr. Williams' Pink Pills. Now I can do any amount of work without fatigue."

Dr. Williams' Pink Pills for Pale People make Good, Rich Blood; they have repeatedly cured Anaemia, Indigestion, Palpitations, Rheumatism. Sciatica. Neuralgia, St. Vitas' Dance, eczema, Nervous Disorders, Paralysis, Effects if Overwork or Worry, also Ladies Ailments. div.head: Army of Occupation
div.p: Egypt Royal Engineer District.
Notice to Builders and Contractors.

Separate tenders are required for the contracts enumerated below for the performance of such works and repairs, and the supply of such building materials, as may be ordered for War Department buildings and property in the above district from the 1st day of December, 1906,to the 31st March 1909 inclusive, viz :—
No. 1 Contract. Cairo (including Citadel, Mokattem and Abbassia).
No. 2 Contract. Alexandria (including Ram- leb, Abonkir and Mex Rifie Range )

Forms of tender with conditions of contract, schedules of prices, and further information can be obtained on application to the Commanding Royal Engineer, Head Quarter Offices, Cairo, on any week day between the hours of 10 a.m. and 1 p.m. up to the 25tb November, 1906, after which no forms will be issued.
A payment of £2 will be required of each candidate for the Schedule of prices. This sum will be returned on receipt of the Schedule of prices from the unsuccessful candidates.
Candidates tendering are requested to send in testimonials of competency to perform both jobbing repairs and buildings, also the nature and extent of their workshops plant and staff of mechanics.

Tenders must be delivered at the Head Quarter Offices, Cairo, by 12 o'clock noon in the 28th November, 1906. addressed to the "General Officer Commanding" and marked on the outside; 'Tender for Artificers' work at 'Alexandria' or Cairo'."
The General Officer Commanding does not bind himself to accept the lowest or any tender.
A.W. Roper, Colonel,
C.R.E. in Egypt.
Cairo November 15, 1906. 288&9-6-6

div.head: Army and Navy
div.p: The command of the 2nd Battalion Leicestershire Regiment, which recently arrived at Belgaum from England, has just changed hands, Brevet Colonel E. R. Scott, whose tenure bad expired, having been replaced by Lieutenant Colonel V. T. Bunbnry, D.S.O., from second in command. The new chief of the battalion has served since 1879 in the Royal Sussex Regiment, the Buffs and Leicester. He was employed with the Egyptian Army, 1835 -1901, and has seen service in various lands, including the Burmsse Expedition, 1889 (medal with clasp); Dongola Expedition, 1895 (mentioned in despatches, medal with two clasps) ; and the Nile Expeditions of 1897 98 99, including the battles of Khartoum (mentioned in despatches, D.S.O., three clasps, British medal).
Captain J. W. H. Seppings, Royal Dublin Fusiliers, who has been serving for some time with the Army Pay Department, in Egypt, has been permanently appointed to that department.

Lieutenant E. A. FitzGerald, the senior subaltern of the 5th Dragoon Guards, Blomfontein, 0. R. C., has been transferred to the 6th Inniskilling Dragoons, Cairo, and promoted captain. Captain FitzGerald joined the ''Green Horse" in July 1900, from the ranks of the Imperial Yeomanry at the front. He saw considerable service with the Yeomanry in the South African War, 1899 i 900 (Queen's medal with two clasps).

Second Lieutenant J. E. P. Howey, Dorsetshire Imperial Yeomanry: and Second Lieutenant J. Whitworth, Royal 1st Devon Imperial Yeomanry, and Second Lieutenant J. Whitworth, Royal 1st Devon Imperial Yeomanry, have been selected for attachment to the 6th Inniskilling Dragoons, Cairo, for where they will leave England at an early date.

It is understood that the Army Council is re considering their disbandment schemes. The 63rd Company R. G. A., which is on the way home from St. Helena, is not to be disbanded on arrival. This company, which has served in almost every quarter of the globe, dates from 1705. The disbandment of such an ancient unit, apart from any other standpoint, would have been a downright scandal.

Owing to the large number of men of the Irish Guards who have been permitted to convert their service on transfer to the Army Reserve, this unit has now nearly reached its reduced establishment, and it is therefore notified that every endeavor should be made to obtain recruits at the increased standard of height, laid down in Army Order 188 of 1906, in view of the necessity of meeting the ordinary wastage and keeping the unit up to establishment.

Vice Admiral Lord Charles Beresford, Commander in Chief of the Mediterranean Fleet, has been formally promoted to the rank of Admiral. As already announced in these notes, he will assume the command of the Channel Fleet—a force of sixteen battleships, six first- class [cruisers, eight Smaller cruisers, and thirty-six destroyers—in March next, in succession to Admiral Sir A.K. Wilson, V.C., who will vacate that appointment under the age roles.

Captain the Honorable Robert F. Boyle, M.V.O., has been appointed to" the command of the cruiser Bacchaute, which will carry the flag of Rear Admiral Sir Harry Barry, when the latter takes over the command of the Third Cruiser Squadron, attached to the Mediterranean Fleet. Captain Boyle, who is the brother of the Earl of Shannon, Castle Martyr, Co. Cork, has served on the bine since 1877, and reached his present rank just three years ago. He was middy on the Minotaur dating the Egyptian War, 1882 (medal and Khedive's star); and served in the Naval Brigade in the Gambia Expedition, 1894, in which he was dangerously wounded (mentioned in dispatches, medal with clasp).

The first-class battleship Bulwark having been ordered home from the Mediterranean Fleet, Vice Admiral Sir Charles C. Drury, the new commander in chief, will hoist his flag on the battleship Queen when he assumes the command.
Over one hundred of the stokers who were concerted in the recent disturbances at Portsmouth are to be drafted to the ships serving n the Mediterranean Fleet.

div.head: SPORT AT SUEZ
div.p: During Bey ram Suez was once again favoured by a visit from a Cairo team organized by Moberley Bey. The original programme included cricket, football (Association and Rugby), hockey, tennis, golf, billiards, and bridge. Unfortunately Suez was unable to raise a "Rugger" team at the last moment owing to illness combined with the fact that several of their team were suddenly called away.
Cricket.

The first event, cricket, played on Friday, resulted in a win for the visitors. Chiefly owing to some sound batting by Rivers Smith and Moberley and the excellent bowling of Wyatt, Cairo gained an easy victory by 122 runs. For the home team Ekins bowled well. scores : —

Total : Suez, 132 games; Cairo, 84.
Football.

Suez were undoubtedly lucky in drawing the football on Saturday afternoon as the visitors played the more scientific game. Cairo, although having much the better of the game in the first half, only managed to score once, while Suez playing up hard in the second half, managed to equalize. The following were the teams:—
Cairo. - Moberley, Wyatt, Brereton, Rowe, Barnard, Shoebridge, Williams, Tiddy, Rivers- Smitbh Deaoon, and Hammond.
Suez.—Menzies, Coombes, Hayes, Hopkin- son, Mansell, Shaddock, Ekins, Brett, Pittuok, Foden, and Dowson.
In the evening the Cairo team were entertained at dinner at the Hotel Bel-Air. After the toasts an excellent impromptu concert was held, the majority of the items being rendered by the visitors.
The hockey on Monday resulted in a win for Suez by 4 goals to nil, as also did the singles at tennis the same afternoon.
Hockey.
Cairo.—Hughes, Hammond, Rowe, Shoebridge, Rivers-Smitb, Tiddy, Caillard, Williams. Barnard, Brereton and Deacon.
Suez.—Menzies. Massey, Battiscombe, Shaddock, Blyth, Pittnck, Mansell. Foden, Dowson, Carpenter and Madge.
Tennis Singles
Messrs. Mansell, Merzies, Ekins, and Quintana (Suez) beat Messrs. Brereton, Barnard, Rivers-Smith, and Hughes by 93 games to 48.

"J.R.'' writes to the "Times'' with reference to the above as follows: — ''Some two years and a-half ago an English princess went up to Khartoum laid the foundation- stone of the proposed English church there. To the native population it was the most natural proceeding in the world. When a leading Moslem in Khartoum was asked if the building of a Christian church would be resented by the Moslems, he answered 'Certainly not. We should have been surprised if yon English had not built.' There was never any doubt about Gordon's faith. His fellow countrymen surely held the same faith. If so, they must have a place in which to worship. The foundation- stone was laid, and for two years nothing more was done Service was held for the English community, as before, in a room in the Government house. There were not sufficient funds to continue the building. One may fairly suppose that this delay has puzzled many a native mind. English men and women have come and stood in front of Gordon's statue at Khartoum admiring it. Tourists have questioned eagerly anyone who could talk of Gordon. They have made no secret of glorying in his name. And yet about that which marked Gordon so particularly—the religious character of the man— English people have been apparently indifferent. But now things are looking up. Building operations are to be resumed. Major Phipps, bon. secretary of the church building fund at Khartoum, writes that, out of the £6,000 necessary for the first part of the building he has £5,000 in hand. An appeal in the 'Record" of September 7 brought in £1,200. Sorely a few of 'The Times' readers could easily contribute the last £1,000. It is almost a matter of national honour that Khartoum should have an English church, and a really fine church."

Mrs. O. D. Robinson, 43 St. Felix St„ Brooklyn, N. Y., writes:
" I have taken Peruna and it did me more good than all my two years treatment by special physicians.

"I can really say that I feel like another person. No more swollen feet and limbs. No more bloating of the abdomen. No more shortness of breath. No more stiff and sore joints. Yon have no idea what your treatment has done for me. It has prolonged my life and made a new woman of me.
"O, such a blessing I have received through your kindness, Doctor, and the assistance of the medicine which you so kindly prescribed.
"I am able to work since I began your treatment, but before I was not able to help myself, much less do any work. All praise is due to Dr. Hartman and his treatment."

Le rapport da Census Bareaa donnant I'd- grenage aa 15 novembre comme 6tant de

bailee, contre 7.498.000, a fait pitcher la baasse par pre»qae toates leB maisoLB d'Amdrique ayant des relations aveo notre place ; anjoord'hoi, ponrtant, il n'y a plus d'uuanimitl d'opiuion et d'aocuns affirmant que le dit rapport va Sire l'objet d'ane revision. Toot est possible, mais ce qui n'ea est pas moins vrai est qae, saaf cette revision, les cbiffies 6ncnc6s par le Bureau de Statistiqae indiqueraient one rdcolte de 12.250.000 k 12 500.000 balles, r6uolte qui serait insuffi- sante. oa k peine saffi-<ante, anx besoins de la consommation si rdeliement, comme on le dit, il y anrait lien k one defalcation de 5 k balles de quality iuatilisable par la filature.

Cbez nons, le mouvement de la reoolte, soit plus exactement les recettes oat sabi one certaine diminution, mais cela tient uniquement aox dispositiors que prend l'Ad- ministration des cbemins de fer pour les p£- riodes feri^es, en vue 4'eviter les eocombre* merits daDs notre g&re. 11 ne s'agit dono que d'ane chose tr&nsitoire et sans importanoe aucune.

Co qui ne s'est pas ralenti par contre, ca sont les eipcrtaiiots qui out fini par d6pas>er lei provisions en atieiguant le total de 3l.8oO balles, contre 27.C00 balles en 1905 ponr la semaine correspondaute.

La eemaine proebaine promet aussi d'etre satiefaisiute ; elle pourrait nOanmoins rester infOrieure aa total de 31.000 bailee environ de 1'anuOe deruiOre, k cause de la question des sospens qai se rOglent d'uffice le dernier joar da mois et qui, poor oettejuis, tombe prOcisO- ment le leudemain de la date k laqaelle le relevO bebdomadaire sera fait !

L'Angleterre vient toojoars bonue premiere avec ees retraits de 34.00<> balles supOrieurs k 1905, tandisqaele continent n'a qu'ane avance de 10,CC0 balle?/contre 8 COO balles de moins poor 1'rimOiique. Li tout en bloo prOsente unc balance de 16.000 balles en faveur de la saison actaelle, mais si ocus prenons toate la position statistique du cotou 6gyptien, il y aarait lien peut-6tre de faire on pea la mone : le stock d'ici est de 181.000 cantara plus fort qa'en 1 f 05 k cette m6me date, le stock de Liverpool est plus gros que celui de i'antle passes, ce qui laisserait supposer que toot ce qui va en I'Angleterre n'est pas encoie vondu k la filature, fandis que le fl ittant est de 13.0^ 0 balles su- p^rieor. Tout cela nous fait one visible supply de 3?0.0'i0 cantara de plus qu'en 1905, aveO nne perspective de rccevoir encore de I'intlriear
0 aatres oautars de plus qae l'ann6e demikre. Cela compte pour que'que chose.
Le march6 du disponible a marque d'en- vergure, mais qaand mfime il peat 6tre corsi- ddr4 comme ayant etd ass' z actif.

Q-ant aux prix, la cote officielle ne nons mmtre ancane d ffereuoe sur veudredi passe, ni pour le Mit-affifi, ni poor les provenances Haute Egypte, k l'exception da Fully good fair et du Good ; oe dernier genre est en baasse de 1/8. Les Abassi et les Joannovich ont par contre avance d'uue fp^m rapide, suit de 5/8 pour les premiers et del 1/4 tal- lari poor les derniers. On monte trop vite et on est k mi niveau as ez extravagant pour les Joannovich poor continuer k mettre en donte ltxistence d'un decoavert, affirn;e du reste p*r les concurrents des malheureux ven- deurs en blano.

La marche de Liverpool a dte quelque pea sarprenbnt pour ce qui regarde les dgyptiens diBponibles sons le rapport des ventes : nons avons ea de 100 k 1000 Balles par joaif, en pageant pre que par toutes les gradations, oe qai iudiquerait qu'il y a ea probablement que'que demande 6»rangkre. vite satbfiite.
CJi.mme prix, le spot est inchang6 k 9 3/8, et le Novembre neperd que 1/64 k la cote de 9 13/64.

L'r\m6ricain a 6t<$ moins actif, mais la oote dn jour nous montre nne baasse- de 14 points sar le spot k 5.99 et de 7 points snr les fatars qui sont k 5.61 pour le Janvier-Fdvrier et k 5.67 poor le Mai-Jain.

div.head: Graines de Coton
div.p: Comme pour les cotons, il y a eu ralentisse- ment dans les ariivages en graines, mais en Somme les besoins coarants ont ete ampleme couverts.

Pour ce qui est des prix, il y a hausse, tant a cause de la demande, que de l'amelioration des contrats. Le dernier prix pratiqul est de P.T. 68. Les exportations sont fortes et pro- mettent de continaer k dtre importantes, non sealement poor le restant de Novembre, mais aussi pour Decembre. Comme noas l'avons dit il y a des besoins en Europe et avaot Janvier les autres graines oleagineuses et la graine de coton de Bombay ne peuvect pas noas entraver dans l'alimentation de la consommation.
La cote de Hall est de £6.16/3d.

En contrats, il y a ea un peu plus d'entrain et quo'que nous ayons reactionne an peu, le cours reste a P.T. 70 1/4 pour le Fevrier-Mars. L'annonce da sauvetage da vapour Coronation avec 6000 T poor Hull et qu'on disait perdu a Mfalte, a calme an peu les esprite.
Ajoutons de plus que le decouvert sur Novembre a du payer 20/40 aa-dessus des cours du F6vrier-Mars poor se racheter.

C'eat ce qai expliqae, avec 1'exoelleDte tenae des cotons, l'animation extra ordinaire qui a dominS dans notre corleille des valears, aa leDdemain des fdtes da Bairam Dapnis la reotrSe des capitalistes, en effet, la semaine qai vient de s'Scoaler, a certainement ete la plas remarqaable boos toas les rapports, bien qa'elle ne comprenneqae qaatre jonrs, la bonrse Stant restSe feraSe eamedi et landi.

Parmi les fluotaations les plas remaiqaables, il nous fact signaler les Nungovich Hotels qai gagDeat 1 livre 3/4 k 20 3/8, la Nile Land 3/4 k 18 1/8 et les parts de fondatear Comptoir 7 livres k 62, par suite de lear fraotioauemeat ea dixikmes, ce qui les read d'an maniemeat plas facile. Li baasse est proportionnellemeat aussi importaate sar la Delta Land qai g&gne 11/32 k 4 13/16, l'lnvestment 5/32 k 1 11/16, 1'Urbaine 9/32 k 7 3/16, le Comptoir 1/4 k 7 3/16. les Splendid Hotels 1/4 k 4 7/16, et le Credit Franoo-Egyptien 1/4 k 5 13/16. div.head: Gouvernment Du Soudan
div.p: Concessions de Terrains a Batir a Port-Soudan
Le Gouvernement du Soudan va prochaine: ment disposer, par voie d'pdjudication d'en- viron 400 parcelles do terrains a batir a Port- Soudan.

Les dites parcelles seront donnees k bail emphyteotique, pour une dur^e de 80 anises a partir du ler Janvier 1907, moyennant loyer annuel, k charge pour le locataire de bktir. Le loyer ne sera payable qu'k partir de la date do I l'acceptation de l'offre.
Les baux, seront renouvelables a perp6tuit6 moyennant un loyer variable fixd a la fin de chaque terme, soit d'accord, soit par arbitrage.
En fixant le nouveau loyer, la valeur des batiments dlevds -par le locataii-e ne sera pas considdrde comme un motif d'augmenta ion de loyer.

EXEMPLE : Si une parcclle de terrain est loude pour une durde de 80 anndes k prtir du ler Janvier 1907. Dans ce cas, k l'exapiration de ce ddlai, le locataire aura un droit (a condition d'observer les conditions du bail) d'obtenir un nouveau bail pour une nouvelle pdriode de 80 anndes, moyennant un loyer modifid, et ainsi premidrp, ! k perpdtuitd
Le loyer modifid sera calculd sur la valeur du terrain, s'il dtait fibre de construction.

Des offros sont demanddes pour les baux emphytdotique.- dont s'agit; ces offres devront mentionner la prime que le soumissionaire est disposd a payer au comptant en sus des loyers annucls dtablis pour chacun des lots. La dite prime devra dtre payde en un seul versement a la signature du contrat do bail.
Toutes offres doivont dtre faites par soumis- sion, sur les formulas dressdes par le Gouvernement du Soudan, et doivent dtre revues k Khartoum avant le ler Janvier 1907.

Le ddtail des terrains offerts, le plan de la ville, les conditions de l'adjudication et de la concession, la formulo de soumission, spdcifica- tion du bail, seront a la disposition du Public a partir du ler Octobre 1906, aux lieux ci-aprds indiquds, durant les heures de bureau.

div.head: A BROKEN-DOWN SYSTEM.
div.p: This is a condition (or disease) to which doctors give many names, but which few of them really understand. It it simply weakness—a break-down, as it were, of the vital forces that sustain the system. No matter what may be its causes (for they are almost numberless), its symptoms are much the same; the more prominent being sleeplessness, sense of prostration or weariness, depression of spirits and want of energy for all the ordinary affairs of life. Now, what alone is absolutely essential in all such cases is increased vitality—vigour--
VITAL STRENGTH & ENERGY
to throw off these morbid feelings, and experience proves that as night succeeds the day this may be more certainly secured by a course of the celebrated life-reviving tonic
THERAPION No.3
than by any other known combination. So surely as it is taken in accordance with the printed directions accompanying it, will the shattered health be restored,
THE EXPIRING LAMP OF LIFE LIGHTED UP AFRESH,

and a new existence imparted in place of what had so lately seemed worn-out, "used up," and valueless. This wonderful medicament is purely vegetable and innocuous, is agreeable to the taste —suitable for all constitutions and conditions, in either sex; and it is difficult to imagine a case of disease or derangement, whose main features are those of debility, that will not be speedily and permanently benefited by this never-failing recuperative essence, which is destined to cast into oblivion everything that had preceded it for this wide-spread and numerous class of human ailments.
